item.title: tan⁻¹(sin(x)) = sin⁻¹(tan(x)/(√(1+tan²(x))))
item.description:
Sure! Let’s provide a step-by-step proof of the identity:

\[ \tan^{-1}(\sin x) = \sin^{-1}\left( \frac{\tan x}{\sqrt{1 + \tan^2 x}} \right) \]

Proof:

  1. \[ y = \tan^{-1}(\sin x) \]
  2. \[ a = \tan(y) \]
  3. \[ \sin x = \tan(y) \]
  4. \[ \tan(y) = \frac{\sin y}{\cos y} \]\[ \sin x = \frac{\tan y}{1 + \tan^2 y} \quad \text{(Using the identity } 1 + \tan^2 y = \sec^2 y) \]
  5. \[ t = \frac{\sin x}{\cos x} \]

    (Using the identity \( \sin x / \cos x = \tan x \))
